channel.title: CultureCase
channel.description: A research resource by Cultural Institute at King’s College London

item.title: Using the ‘audience exchange’ approach to help first-time audiences
item.caption: This paper outlines the use of the ‘audience exchange’ approach to audience development. This involves facilitated group dialogue between audience members who are first-time attenders who may lack confidence or familiarity with the art form they have just encountered.

item.title: How people acquire new tastes in music
item.caption: This study took place over 15 months via a combination of observation and life history interviews with about 30 regulars at a Honky Tonk Night Club in a large mid-western US city.

item.title: The positive impacts of active music participation for infants
item.caption: To understand the developmental impact of active participation in music, this study worked with two groups of six-month old infants who attended music-based sessions with teachers and their parents.

item.title: How learning visual art improves creativity and changes the brain
item.caption: This study investigated the impact of visual art training on young adults’ behaviour and changes in brain activity.

item.title: Managing dementia through object handing in museums
item.caption: The authors of this study propose that the heritage sector could have a role to play in subjective health and wellbeing for individuals with dementia.

item.title: Frequent attendance at cultural events associated with reduced cancer mortality
item.caption: This paper describes a long-term study looking at correlations between taking part in certain cultural activities and cancer mortality.

item.title: Musicians react faster than non-musicians
item.caption: This study aimed to investigate whether long-term musical training improves unisensory (audio or tactile) and multisensory (audio and tactile) processing capacities.
